Development of cationic gallium phthalocyanine catalysts for the chemistry of donor-acceptor cyclopropanes and its reactions with aldehydes Anastasia A. Levina 1 Roman A. Novikov ⁎ 1 Denis D. Borisov Maxim A. Novikov Yury V. Tomilov ⁎ N. D. Zelinsky Institute of Organic Chemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, 47 Leninsky prosp., 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation N. D. Zelinsky Institute of Organic Chemistry Russian Academy of Sciences 47 Leninsky prosp. Moscow 119991 Russian Federation N. D. Zelinsky Institute of Organic Chemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, 47 Leninsky prosp., 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 A.A.L.and R.A.N.contributed equally. Cationic gallium phthalocyanine (RPcGa+) catalysts with SbF6 – and Sb2F11 –/Sb3F16 – weakly coordinating anions were developed and used in the catalytic chemistry of donor-acceptor (D–A) cyclopropanes and related substrates. For the first time, these processes were implemented on the examples of [3 + 2]-cycloaddition/annulation reactions of D–A cyclopropanes and styrylmalonates with various aldehydes, as well as some other transformations with different substrates. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Donor-acceptor cyclopropanes Gallium phthalocyanines Ionic complexes Aromatic aldehydes Catalysis Stereoselectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Donor-acceptor cyclopropanes (D–A cyclopropanes, DAC) are known for their ability to readily undergo opening of the three-membered ring [1,2] and enter cycloaddition reactions [3–5]. They are now widely used in synthetic organic chemistry and in related fields [6–8] and therefore do not require a special presentation. The scope of DAC chemistry became so wide due to the uniqueness of these molecules. Despite the simplicity of their structure, it combines many opportunities for multifunctionality [1–5]. Furthermore, they can act as a diverse synthons and building blocks [9,10]. It means that one can obtain products with various structures, sometimes counting even a dozen [3g], from the same simple starting compounds by varying the reaction conditions only [3–5]. Simple gallium compounds showed themselves especially well in this area, as in recent years they made it possible to significantly expand the range of DAC reactions [11–13] and extend them to related substrates, in particular, isomeric styrylmalonates as synthetic DAC equivalents [14] and methylidenemalonates [15] (Knoevenagel reaction products) (Scheme 1 ). Unfortunately, many reactions of this family (with rare exceptions) require equimolar amounts of gallium halides (GaHal3), usually 1–2 equivalents [11–15], which is an obvious drawback. In addition, if equimolar amounts of a mediator are used, it is extremely difficult to perform enantioselective reactions and isolation of products obtained. Data on the use of ligands for catalysis by Ga compounds are practically lacking in the literature [16]. Thus, the use of gallium compounds as Lewis acids in synthetic organic chemistry is limited to GaHal3 and Ga(OTf)3 [17]. Perhaps, NHC complexes of GaCl3 (IPrGaCl3) represent the only exception and a well-developed example of ligand stabilization (by C. Bour and V. Gandon group) [18,19]. The IPrGaCl3 complex requires activation with AgSbF6 and is widely used as a π-Lewis acid in reactions of cyclization and addition to triple and double C–C bonds [18,19], in Friedel-Crafts alkylation, etc. [20]. An only example of the use of IPrGaCl3 for catalyzing DAC reactions is also known [21]. However, it should be noted that the majority of the known IPrGaCl3-catalyzed reactions (with all the advantages of the latter) are fairly well catalyzed by the usual GaCl3 [22]. Results and discussion Recently [23], we have shown that cationic gallium phthalocyanines (RPcGa+) with SbF6 – and Sb2F11 – weakly coordinating anions can be used in the catalytic version for the typical [3 + 2]-annulation reaction of styrylmalonate 1 with benzaldehyde with the formation of indene 2, which in the most known mode still required the use of 2 equiv. anhydrous GaCl3 [14a,d]. For this purpose, a generation of 4–6 mol.% tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – or tBu4PcGa+Sb2F11 – as a new Ga-catalysts was used (Scheme 2 , A) [23]. At the next step (in this work), as the initial model for studying the catalytic capability of substituted cationic gallium phthalocyanines R n PcGa+SbF6 –toward D–A cyclopropanes and for methodology refinement we chose the readily occurring and well-studied formal [3 + 2]-cycloaddition of 2-arylcyclopropane-1,1-dicarboxylates 3 to aromatic aldehydes [24–26] as a most typical process for DAC (Scheme 2, B). Many Lewis acids, in particular Sn(OTf)2, MgI2, SnCl4, Sc(OTf)3, etc., perform fairly well in this reaction [25]. However, the yields of the target tetrahydrofurans 4 (THF) and their diastereomeric ratios vary markedly. Catalytic amounts of Sn(OTf)2 (typically 5 mol.%) are usually employed for highly active aromatic aldehydes [25]. The reactions of less reactive DACs and aldehydes, including aliphatic aldehydes, are usually performed in the presence of SnCl4 [25]. An example involving the use of cobalt porphyrin (CoTPP) for catalyzing this reaction is also known [26d]. It should be noted that GaCl3 was not studied in this reaction yet. Catalyzed [3 + 2]-cycloaddition of D–A cyclopropanes with aldehydes We compared the catalytic activity of various Lewis acids in reaction of DAC 3a with benzaldehyde primarily focused on PcGa-based and related catalysts (Fig. 1 , Scheme 3 ), and tried to study the main regularities. The main challenge was not only to develop a better methodology than the use of the known Sn(OTf)2-catalysis, but also to introduce the new [PcGa] catalysts in the DAC chemistry (Table 1 ). 10 mol.% of GaCl3 works well in this reaction and gives a yield of 4a in 90%, however with poor diastereoselectivity, but 100 mol.% of GaCl3 gives bad results (Table 1, Entries 3, 4). GaCl3 in equimolar amounts is too highly active and low selective, which leads to complex mixtures. For example, in some cases we obtained the mixture of dimers of starting DAC and ring-opened chlorinated malonate without target THF in case using 100 mol.% of GaCl3. The conversion of starting DAC was 100%. Complex tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – that can be prepared both “pre in situ” [23,27], practically without an impurity of Ag salts, and directly “in situ” is the most efficient catalytic system under formation of tetrahydrofuran 4a. The tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – ionic complex (3–5 mol.%) performs very well (Table 1, Entry 10). Its structure in DCM/DCE solution was verified by complex NMR analysis. It should be noted specially that it is important to obtain tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – without a noticeable AgSbF6 admixture in order to get clear results, because the latter compound can also catalyze this particular reaction (Table 1, Entries 5, 6). The simplest method involves the use of a small excess of tBu4PcGaCl with respect to AgSbF6 (typically 5 mol.% and 4 mol.%, respectively), which allows one to remove Ag+ almost completely as insoluble AgCl from the reaction zone [28]. It should be noted that tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – and AgSbF6 differ in reactivity, which primarily manifests itself in a very different isomer ratio in the resulting tetrahydrofurans: 21/1 for [PcGa] versus 3/1 for [Ag] (Table 1, Entries 5 and 10). Thus, tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – shows much better diastereoselectivity than AgSbF6. The tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – is unstable in its pure form. We tested both resulting mixtures of tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – with and without separation of AgCl precipitate and saw that the yield of target THF was similar in all cases. The AgCl precipitate itself does not catalyze these processes, which was also confirmed in a separate experiment. (Table 1, Entry 11). The nBu8PcGa+SbF6 – complex also catalyzes the process, but it is markedly less active. However, it provides an even better diastereoselectivity (65/1, Table 1, Entry 14), which can be used in targeted synthesis. This effect is apparently due to the presence of eight n‑butyl groups along the perimeter of the phthalocyanine ring, despite their remoteness from the central Ga-active center. In addition, the diastereoselectivity can be significantly increased at lower reaction temperature and longer times (Table 2 , Entries 6 and 7). Another cationic complex, tBu4PcGa+GaCl4 – obtained by an independent method without the use of silver salts, also catalyzes [3 + 2]-cycloaddition (Table 1, Entry 12). As expected [23], initial gallium phthalocyanines tBu4PcGaCl and nBu8PcGaCl showed no catalytic activity (Table 1, Entries 9 and 13), which confirms the importance of the PcGa+ cation. It is interesting to note that the similar aluminum phthalocyanine tBu4PcAlCl almost fails to catalyze this process, even after activation with AgSbF6 (Table 1, Entries 7 and 8). The Al3+cation has a smaller radius than Ga3+ and is therefore located in the Pc plane [23], which results in its strong deactivation and difficult approach of reagents. In addition, abstraction of Cl from Al can be hindered significantly. Detailed optimization of the reaction conditions (Table 2) allows the yield of a THF-product 4a to be increased up to ∼100% (Entry 3). The use of 3 mol.% tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – and 1.5 equiv. benzaldehyde with respect to DAC is the optimum mode. It should be noted that 1 equiv. of benzaldehyde can also be used. In this case, the yield of the target product decreases insignificantly (Table 2, Entry 4). It should also be noted that early 3 equiv. ArCHO was typically used in this process [25]. The lower limit of the catalyst amount used under the optimum reaction conditions (1,2-DCE, +83 °C) is about 2 mol.% (Table 2, Entry 2 and 8), which is apparently due to the “hydrolytic instability” of the complex. In other words, [Ga+] is simply deactivated by traces of water below this limit (or other impurities). However, exact reasons are unknown. So, the same scale-up experiments with 5 mmol of DAC lead to observation of the same regularities. On the other hand, in principle, smaller amounts of the catalyst can also be used (although it is not advisable), but this requires either special methods of purification from traces of moisture and sophisticated experimental techniques, or raising the reaction temperature (Table 2, Entries 9 and 10). At the same time, like in some other cases shown in Table 2, conversion of the initial DAC decreases noticeably. It was also important to study the effect of various weakly coordinating anions (WCA) on the activity of tBu4PcGa+(Table 3 ). It should be noted that the SbF6 – anion was chosen intentionally after optimization, since it activates most strongly and is affordable. WCA were incorporated into the [PcGa+] structure via the corresponding silver salts (AgWCA) by Cl– abstraction. It was found that TfO– and ClO4 – were practically inactive (weakly active) in the reaction under consideration; Tf2N– showed moderate catalytic activity, but nevertheless it was much inferior to hexafluoroantimonate. Surprisingly, 2,5-diphenyltetrahydrofuran-3,3-dicarboxylate 4a was almost not formed in the case of BF4 – or PF6 –. The reason of that apparently lies in the transfer of a fluorine anion to the gallium atom [18b] to give inactive tBu4PcGa–F. In contrast, the complex Sb2F11 – and Sb3F16 – anions are significantly more active, due to extra decrease of basicity by additional [SbF5] units. But they require a special approach to clear synthesis (see a Section below and [23]). The AsF6 – anion is similar to hexafluoroantimonate, but predictably less active (Table 3). Scope of the [3 + 2]-cycloaddition of D–A cyclopropanes with aldehydes Once we reached an understanding of the basic regularities, we thoroughly studied the scope of the [3 + 2]-cycloaddition of various DAC 3 to aromatic aldehydes and the applicability of RPcGa+SbF6 – as a catalyst (Fig. 2 ). In most cases, we tested and compared the catalytic ability of both phthalocyanine complexes, tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – and nBu8PcGa+SbF6 –. In some cases, we did not bring the reaction conditions to the optimum but limited ourselves to comparing them under standard conditions, since we intended to study the principal applicability of this process in the first place. The reactions occur well with a wide range of substituted substrates. In fact, DACs substituted at the para position, including those with the MeO group, as well as the naphthyl and thienyl moieties well enter this reaction (Fig. 2). Meta-substituted DACs are predictably less reactive and require more drastic conditions. Ortho-substituted DACs and DACs with acceptor substituents (NO2, CF3) are even less reactive [29]. The reaction occurs very slowly under standard conditions; however, it can be activated under more drastic conditions, or using tBu4PcGa+Sb2F11 – as catalyst [23]. For these low active D–A cyclopropanes, a special catalytic approach has also been developed, a description of which is given below. Varying aromatic aldehydes imposes noticeably less restrictions on their reactivity, and the reactions occur successfully in nearly all cases (Fig. 2). One can use benzaldehydes with substituents at various positions, other aromatic aldehydes with polyaromatic and various heteroaromatic substituents, as well as cinnamaldehydes. It is also interesting to use phthalic dialdehydes that allow one to obtain products of both mono- and diaddition, depending on the ratio of the starting reagents. Substituted tetrahydrofurans can be also successfully obtained by changing the substituents simultaneously in a DAC and in an aldehyde. The reaction also occurs with aliphatic aldehydes, especially successfully with aldehydes containing secondary alkyl substituents (Fig. 2). Thus, catalysis with RPcGa+SbF6 – is of general scope. In the future it may be expanded to various transformations and substituted substrates. Based on the scope described above, we can consider the basic regularities for the [3 + 2]-cycloaddition process as a whole. In most cases, it is well catalyzed with 3 mol.% RPcGa+SbF6 – (at +83 °C in 1,2-DCE), but in some cases longer reaction times than the standard 3 h are required. For less reactive combinations of substrates, up to 10 mol.% of the catalyst or more can be used and the reaction temperature can be increased (to +131 °C in PhCl without considerable degradation). Typically, nBu8PcGa+SbF6 – is less reactive than tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – but provides better diastereoselectivity. However, with a number of strong donor substituents diastereoselectivity is poor in both cases, which is however due not to the reaction itself but to some epimerization of the cis-isomer of the THF product 4 to the trans-isomer under the reaction conditions and is a common problem for all known Lewis acids [25,26]. Though this reaction is well studied, the majority of the substituted THF 4 we obtained are new unreported compounds [25,26]. Tetrahydrofurans (THF) evidently belong to the prevalence structurally and biologically very important molecules, for example 5‒9 [24–26]. The THF scaffold is a part of various natural compounds [30,31], such as polyetherionophore antibiotics, lignans [32], c-glycosidases, and others [33] (Fig. 3 ). Its derivatives both natural and synthetic show a very broad spectrum of biological activity, e.g. cytotoxic, antioxidant, antidiabetic, antibiotic, anticancer, anti-inflammatory properties, and various receptor inhibitors [30–33]. They also serve as versatile building blocks in the construction of biologically important compounds [34]. General mechanistic details of the [PcGa+]-catalysis in formal [3 + 2]-cycloaddition process seem to be quite evident; and its mechanism should be similar for literature data of other Lewis acids [24–26]. The [PcGa+] activates cyclopropane molecule by “standard” coordination by CO2Me-groups (Fig. 4 ) [24–26] with subsequent addition of aldehyde. However, the details could be very interesting. To date we were able to found quite reliably by complex NMR analysis several transition ionic complexes [23], in which the aldehyde / cyclopropane molecule is coordinated to cationic Ga+ center in [Pc]. It proves the dominant type of activation, but the real intermediate complexes should be more complicated. In addition, the SbF6 – anion could play a certain role in this process, especially the higher-order Sb2F11 –/Sb3F16 – anions. Additionally, a control experiment was carried out with mono-ester substituted cyclopropane (ethyl 2-phenylcyclopropane-1-carboxylate) and, unfortunately, this catalytic system did not work in the [3 + 2]-cycloaddition reaction with benzaldehyde (Fig. 4). Most likely, bicoordination plays an important role in this process. For mono-substituted cyclopropanes, much more stringent reaction conditions may be required, since these cyclopropane substrates will be much less reactive with any catalysts. Other RPcGa+SbF6 – catalyzed reactions of D–A cyclopropanes and related substrates The next step was to test other reactions and the transition to Ga-specific reactions for various D–A substrates. It should be noted that this is not the primary purpose of this work but the next conceptual step, which requires further development and improvement of Ga-based catalysts based on the data obtained in the current work. [PcGa] whose capabilities were first demonstrated in this paper represents just the first generation of Ga-catalysts. Nevertheless, in order to get initial data for further studies and to demonstrate the principal possibility of performing catalytic “Ga-specific” processes, we studied a series of similar reactions for three different D–A objects, namely, styrylmalonate 1, DAC 3, and D–A cyclobutane 10 (DACB) [35], including reactions currently known for GaCl3 only [11,14] (Fig. 5 ). The first class of processes involved the classic 1,3-zwitterionic chemistry implemented in a catalytic version with the use of tBu4PcGa+SbF6 –. In this case, there are generally no problems and the reactions occur under “standard conditions” (DCE, +80–85 °C). Nu-addition (2-pyrazoline) [36] 11 and Friedel-Crafts alkylation (trimethoxybenzene) [37] of classical DAC 12, as well as [4 + 2]-cycloaddition of benzaldehyde to DACB 13 [35c] were demonstrated as the test reactions (Fig. 5). The implementation of the three typical processes was shown using this approach (Fig. 4). Starting from styrylmalonate as a DAC equivalent, [2 + 3]-annulation with benzaldehyde to form indene 2 [14a,23] and styrene [4 + 2]-cycloaddition to give tetralin 14 [11a,b,23] were carried out in the catalytic version [38]. A 1,2-zwitterionic process of intramolecular cyclization of DACB to the corresponding indane 15 was also implemented. These reactions represent the first examples of a Ga-catalyzed version of such processes previously known only in the case of activation with equimolar amounts of GaCl3. The implementation of gallium-specific processes for the same substrates [11,12,14,15] with catalysis by tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – is a much more difficult task since these reactions require a highly active Ga center, which is activated insufficiently [11a,b,14a] in “conventional” tBu4PcGa+. As a result, there are two ways to overcome it (Fig. 4). The first one is to use a high process temperature (typically 130–140 °C in 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane (TCE)) (or TCE-d 2 for experiments in NMR tubes). The second way is to additionally activate the Ga+ center in [Pc] using less basic complex Sb2F11 – and Sb3F16 – anions, than simple SbF6 – (Fig. 5). Additionally, the catalytic [nBu4N]+SbF6 – and [nHex4N]+Sb2F11 – additives can be applied to stabilize the transition states by the creating excess of WCA. We have developed a quite simple approach to their synthesis “pre in situ” based on strictly controlled sequential introduction of SbF5 units, and special process conditions, e.g. using perfluorinated solvents (Fig. 6 , A) [23]. As one can see, the RPcGa+SbF6 – complexes have excellent potential for further development of their catalytic chemistry. Gallium phthalocyanine catalysts with increased activity for reactions of low active substrates As noted above, an effective way to additionally activate the Ga+ center in [Pc] is to use less basic complex Sb2F11 – and Sb3F16 – anions, than simple SbF6 – (Fig. 6, A). Additionally, the catalytic [nBu4N]+SbF6 – and [nHex4N]+Sb2F11 – additives can be applied to stabilize the transition states by the creating excess of WCA. We have developed a quite simple approach to their synthesis “pre in situ” based on strictly controlled sequential introduction of SbF5 units, and special process conditions, e.g. using perfluorinated solvents (Fig. 6, A). Corresponding tBu4PcGa+Sb2F11 –/Sb3F16 – are highly active as catalysts, that has been also demonstrated in model [3 + 2]-cycloaddition process (Fig. 6, B) and in some other Ga-specific processes (Fig. 5). Application in the [3 + 2]-cycloaddition process allows to reduce significantly the reaction temperature and time (compare with "conventional" tBu4PcGa+SbF6 –) with preservation close to quantitative yields of the product 4a (Fig. 6, B), and introduce less active substrates into the reaction. It should be noted that the high activity of the tBu4PcGa+Sb2F11 –/Sb3F16 –catalyst is apparently due to the cooperative action of the gallium cation with increased electrophilicity and cluster Sb2F11 –/Sb3F16 – anions. The fact that the latter can reversibly release into solution free SbF5, which can also catalyze the process independently, but this does not explain a high observed catalytic activity. Control experiments of catalysis using free SbF5 at different concentrations show a much worse results and the occurrence of many side reactions (Fig. 6, B). The use of tBu4PcGa+Sb2F11 –/Sb3F16 – catalysts is effective, but somewhat difficult in experimental terms. To overcome these shortcomings, we have developed another simpler way to increase the activity of the basic tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – catalyst. Even when working out the reaction conditions (Table 1, Fig. 1), we noticed that phthalocyanine with donor phenoxy substituents ((4-FC6H4O)8PcGa+SbF6 –) almost does not have the catalytic activity. In general, this is not surprising, since the introduction of eight donor groups significantly reduces the electrophilicity of the gallium cation. Accordingly, with the introduction of acceptor groups, the opposite effect should be observed, with an increase in the electrophilicity of gallium cationic center and an increase in catalytic activity. Thus, we have synthesized nitro-substituted tBu4PcGa phthalocyanine (Fig. 7 ). The simplest method of synthesis turned out to be direct nitration of the starting readily available phthalocyanine tBu4PcGaCl [23] with the nitronium boron tetrafluoride (NO2 +BF4 –). Under these conditions, three nitro groups are introduced into phthalocyanine (with an admixture of dinitro derivative) (formed as a mixture of regio-isomers). The target phthalocyanine after nitration is formed with replacing the chlorine atom with a fluorine atom at gallium (tBu4(NO2)3PcGaF), because the affinity of gallium for fluorine is high and higher than that of boron in BF4 – anion. This is not good due to the inactivity of the Ga–F bond, therefore, the fluorine atom has to be additionally abstracted with the addition of SbF5, which leads to the target active tBu4(NO2)3PcGa+SbF6 – catalyst. The synthesized tBu4(NO2)3PcGa+SbF6 – catalyst is a highly active, three acceptor nitro-groups into phthalocyanine core significantly increase the activity of the gallium cation. We have tested it into [3 + 2]-cycloaddition reaction of D–A cyclopropanes 3 with benzaldehyde, when very low active D–A cyclopropanes 3j‒l with acceptor aryl substituents (NO2, CF3, 2,6-Cl2 in Ph-ring) were used (Fig. 8 ). In this case, standard tBu4PcGa+SbF6 – catalyst does not work, and even the well-established tin(II) triflate (Sn(OTf)2) for this reaction doesn't work either. On the contrary, tBu4(NO2)3PcGa+SbF6 – works well and shows high activity for these low activity cyclopropanes (Fig. 8). It should be noted that such "acceptor" D–A cyclopropanes are practically not used in organic synthesis, precisely for reasons of too low activity. On the other hand, the gallium(III) atom has an excellent ability to cleavage such "acceptor" cyclopropanes, which has been also shown in particular in previous works on the use of equimolar amounts of GaCl3. Thus. this demonstrates the high potential of gallium phthalocyanine catalysts and their practical utility. Conclusions In conclusion, we have developed the first generation of gallium catalysts based on cationic gallium phthalocyanines (RPcGa+) with SbF6 – and Sb2F11 –/Sb3F16 – weakly coordinating anions. The main challenge is to use them in the catalytic version for gallium-specific chemistry of donor-acceptor cyclopropanes (DAC) and related substrates. For the first time, these processes were implemented in the catalytic version by the example of [4 + 2]-annulation with styrene and reactions of [3 + 2]-cycloaddition/annulation of DAC and styrylmalonates with various aldehydes, as well as some other transformations. We have also studied some mechanistic aspects of these catalytic processes. Author statement Anastasia A. Levina: Investigation, Methodology; Roman A. coredata.dc:description: Cationic gallium phthalocyanine (RPcGa+) catalysts with SbF6 – and Sb2F11 –/Sb3F16 – weakly coordinating anions were developed and used in the catalytic chemistry of donor-acceptor (D–A) cyclopropanes and related substrates. For the first time, these processes were implemented on the examples of [3 + 2]-cycloaddition/annulation reactions of D–A cyclopropanes and styrylmalonates with various aldehydes, as well as some other transformations with different substrates.
coredata.dc:title: Development of cationic gallium phthalocyanine catalysts for the chemistry of donor-acceptor cyclopropanes and its reactions with aldehydes
